bcl:subsection.bcl:text: In this Act:

bcl:text.#text:
means the Workers' Compensation Board established under the
              ;

includes a child to whom the victim stands in the place of a
            parent;
means

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a spouse, child, sibling, step-sibling, half sibling or parent of the victim
              or a person who, although not a parent or child of the victim, was like a parent or
              child to the victim and, for this purpose

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
spouse means the individual recognized under subsection (2) as the spouse
                of the victim, and

child includes an individual recognized under subsection (2) as the child
                of the victim and, with reference to the victim as parent, a child born after the
                death of the victim, or

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
if dependent in whole or in part on the victim for financial support at the
              time of the victim's death, a grandparent or grandchild of the victim;

bcl:text.#text:
and  means bodily harm, and includes
            mental or nervous shock and pregnancy;
means physically or mentally incapable of earning;

means a physician listed by the Royal College of
            Physicians and Surgeons of Canada as having specialist qualifications;
means a person who

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: is married to another person, or
is living with another person in a marriage-like relationship;

bcl:text.#text:
means a person injured or killed in the circumstances set out
            in section 2
              (2).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The board may recognize an individual as the spouse or child of the victim for the
          purposes of this Act if at the time of the victim's death the individual

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
was qualified as a spouse or child of the victim under an enactment of British
            Columbia or Canada to apply for support, alimony or maintenance from the victim,
            or

was entitled to support, alimony or maintenance from the victim under an order
            or agreement enforceable under such an enactment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Repealed 2001-38-32 and B.C. Reg. 160/2002.]

For the purpose of this Act, a victim of crime is a person injured or killed in
          British Columbia by an act or omission of another resulting from any of the
          following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the commission of an offence within the description of a criminal offence
            mentioned in the Schedule, except an offence arising out of the
            operation of a motor vehicle, but including assault by means of a motor
            vehicle;

the lawful arrest or attempt to arrest an offender or suspected offender, or
            assisting a peace officer in making or attempting to make an arrest;

the lawful prevention or attempt to prevent the commission of a criminal offence
            or suspected offence, or assisting a peace officer in preventing or attempting to
            prevent the commission of the offence or suspected offence.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
On application as prescribed by the board or by the regulations, the
          board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
must determine whether the applicant is a victim of crime or the immediate
            family member of a deceased victim of crime, and

may award compensation to the victim or the immediate family members as provided
            by this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to subsections (4.1) and (4.2), compensation may be awarded for any of the
          following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
expenses actually and reasonably incurred or to be incurred as a result of the
            victim's injury or death;

pecuniary loss or damages incurred by the victim as a result of total or partial
            disability affecting the victim's capacity for work;

pecuniary loss or damages incurred by immediate family members as a result of
            the victim's death;
maintenance of a child born as a result of rape;

other pecuniary loss or damages resulting from the victim's injury and any
            expense that, in the board's opinion, it is reasonable to incur;

non-pecuniary loss or damage for pain, suffering, mental or emotional trauma,
            humiliation or inconvenience.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Despite any provision of this Act, compensation referred to in subsection (4)
            (f) may not be awarded under this Act in respect of an application received
          by the board on or after April 16, 2002.

Subsection (4.1) applies irrespective of the date of death or injury in respect of
          which an application is made and whether or not the board has extended the period for
          making an application under section 6.

If the injury to a person occurred in the circumstances mentioned in subsection (2)
            (b) or (c) the board may, in addition to the compensation referred to in
          subsection (4), award compensation to the injured person for any other damage resulting
          from the injury for which compensation may be recovered at law, other than punitive or
          exemplary damages.
The board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
award compensation to a mother who is herself maintaining a child born to her as
            a result of an offence in the Schedule, and

if the mother dies, pay compensation to any person who, in the board's opinion,
            is maintaining the child.

bcl:text.#text:
Compensation awarded to an applicant under this Act must be paid out of the
          consolidated revenue fund in the same manner as money is paid under the , if a worker, employed by the government, is
          injured or killed in the course of his or her employment.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The board may, in its discretion exercised in accordance with this Act, do any of
          the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: award compensation in the form of periodic payments, and

bcl:text.#text:
if the periodic payments are awarded to a victim who is disabled as a result
              of an injury, they must, subject to this Act, be of the same amount and for the same
              duration as payments made to a disabled worker under sections 22, 23, 29 and 30 of the
              , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 492, as those sections read
              before being amended by the

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
may commute all or part of the periodic payments to one or more lump sum
              payments, to be applied as directed by the board;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
if compensation is payable for expenses, pay the compensation directly to the
            person entitled to it.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
An award of compensation may be made subject to terms and conditions the board
          considers necessary or advisable with respect to the any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: payment, disposition, allotment or apportionment of the compensation;

payment of compensation to any person who, in the board's opinion, is best
            qualified to administer the payment on behalf of a victim or immediate family member who
            is, in the board's opinion, incapable of managing his or her own affairs.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Subject to section 5, in determining whether to award compensation and the amount, the
          board must have regard to all relevant circumstances, including any behaviour of the
          victim that may have, directly or indirectly, contributed to his or her injury or
          death.

bcl:text:
In determining the amount of compensation, if any, to be awarded to an applicant,
          the board must deduct

under an Act of Canada or of British Columbia or of any other province other
          than benefits under a pension plan or program under such an Act, and, if the claim is
          for injuries or death caused by a motor vehicle, includes benefits that could have been
          applied for under a policy of accident insurance, and

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
any amount recovered from the person whose act or omission resulted in the
            injury or death, whether as damages or compensation, under an action at law or
            otherwise, and
any benefits received or to be received

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text: by the victim for the injury, or
by the applicant for the victim's death,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
any payment, allowance or benefit that the victim may receive from his or her
            employer during the period of his or her disability, including a pension, gratuity or
            other allowance provided wholly at the expense of the employer.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The board must not entertain an application under section 2 made for injury or
          death of a peace officer occurring under circumstances entitling the peace officer or the
          peace officer's immediate family members to compensation payable out of public money under
          any other Act of British Columbia or of Canada or payable by an organization that is
          wholly or partly supported by public funds.

The board must not entertain an application if a claim is less than $100 nor make
          an award if the amount payable is less than $100.
The board must not award compensation

bcl:text.#text:
except under section 2 (4) (f), to a victim who is injured in
            circumstances giving recourse to the  (Canada) or the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 492, as it read before being amended by the ,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
to a victim who, through his or her gross fault, contributed to his or her
            injuries or death, or who was a party to the crime,

to an immediate family member who was a party to the offence that caused the
            victim's death, or

to an immediate family member of a victim who was a party to the
            crime.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
An application for compensation must be made within one year after the date of the
        injury or death but the board, before or after the expiry of the one year period, may extend
        the time for a further period as it considers warranted.

The Attorney General may appear and be heard at the hearing of any matter by the
        board under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Compensation may be awarded whether or not any person is prosecuted for or
          convicted of the offence giving rise to the injury or death.

On its own initiative or on the application of the Attorney General, the board may
          adjourn its proceedings until the final determination of a prosecution or intended
          prosecution.

A person is deemed for the purposes of this Act to have intended an act or
          omission that caused injury or death for which compensation is payable under this Act even
          if the person is, for any reason, legally incapable of having a criminal
          intent.

If a person is convicted of a criminal offence for an act or omission on which a
          claim under this Act is based, proof of the conviction is, after the time for an appeal
          has expired or if an appeal was taken, it was dismissed and no further appeal is
          available, conclusive evidence that the offence has been committed.

The board may, in its discretion, order interim payments to the applicant
          if

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the applicant is in actual financial need, and

it appears to the board that it will probably award compensation to the
            applicant.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If compensation is not awarded, the amount paid under this section is not, in the
          absence of fraud or misrepresentation, recoverable from the applicant.

If the cause of the injury or death of the victim is such that an action lies
          against some person, the victim or immediate family member may apply for and receive
          compensation, bring the action or do both.

If a victim or immediate family member who brings the action referred to in
            subsection
            (1) and who, before judgment in or settlement of the action, receives
          compensation under this Act, he or she must immediately notify the board of the
          action.

On applying to the court, the board must be added as a party to the action of
          which it has been notified under subsection (2).

If an action for the injury or death of the victim has not been brought by the
          victim or immediate family member, the board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
is subrogated in respect of the right of action of the victim or immediate
            family member to whom payment is made under this Act, and

may maintain the action in the name of that person or in its own
            name.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The board may not seek compensation under this section for non-pecuniary loss or
          damage for pain, suffering, mental or emotional trauma, humiliation or inconvenience, in
          respect of an application received by the board on or after April 16, 2002.

If the board brings the action referred to in subsection (4), it must give notice
          of the action to the victim or immediate family member, as the case may be.

Neither the making of the application for nor the payment of compensation under
          this Act restricts or impairs a right of action of the board, victim or immediate family
          member against any person liable.

If compensation has been paid or awarded under this Act, the amount recovered from
          the person against whom the action referred to in subsection (1) lies must be
          applied

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
first, to payment of costs, if any, including costs of bringing
            execution,

second, to payment to the victim or immediate family member of the amount, if
            any, by which the amount recovered, less costs under paragraph (a), exceeds the
            compensation paid or to be paid by the board, and

third, to payment to the board for reimbursement of the compensation paid or to
            be paid by it to the victim or immediate family member.

bcl:text:
is less than the amount of compensation paid or awarded by the board, the victim
          or immediate family member remains entitled to retain or to be paid the amount of
          compensation awarded by the board.

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
a judgment awarded by a court in an action referred to in subsection
              (1), or

a settlement of a claim or an action referred to in subsection
              (1),

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A settlement or release does not bar the rights of the board under subsection (4)
          unless the board has concurred in it.

In an action referred to in subsection (4), an award of damages is to include wages
          and salary paid by the employer of the victim.

Costs may be awarded to and collected by the board in an action referred to in
          this section, even if a salaried legal officer of the board acts as solicitor or
          counsel.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
Any compensation awarded or other amount paid or payable by the board under this Act
        is not subject to garnishment, attachment, seizure or any other legal process and the right
        to it is not assignable.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If injury is superimposed on an already existing disability, compensation is to be
          allowed only for the proportion of disability that exists following the injury as may
          reasonably be attributed to the injury.

The measure of the disability attributable to injury is the amount of the
          difference between the victim's disability before and disability after the occurrence of
          the injury.

The amount awarded by the board to be paid for injury or death of a victim must
          not,

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: for a lump sum payment, exceed $50 000, and

bcl:text.#text:
for periodic payments, exceed the amount payable to a worker or dependant under
            sections 17, 22, 23, 29 and 30 of the , R.S.B.C. 1996, c. 492, as those sections read before being amended by the

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If both lump sum and periodic payments are awarded, one but not both may exceed
          50% of the maximum amount that can be awarded under subsection (1) (a) or
          (b).

Subsections (1) and (2) do not apply to amounts awarded in respect of a death or
          injury occurring in the circumstances referred to in section 2 (2) (b) or (c) and the
          amounts must not be taken into account in determining maximum awards.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Duration of payments to immediate family members
bcl:section.bcl:text:
If periodic payments have been awarded under section 3 they are to continue only so
        long as, in the board's opinion, it might reasonably have been expected had the victim lived
        he or she would have continued to contribute to the support of his or her immediate family
        members.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If a victim or an immediate family member is confined to a penitentiary or a
          correctional institution, the board

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
may cancel, withhold or suspend the payment of compensation for a period it
            considers advisable, and

if the compensation is withheld or suspended, may pay the compensation or any
            portion to his or her spouse or children, or to a trustee appointed by the
            board.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A trustee must expend any money paid to the trustee under subsection (1)
          for the benefit of the victim, the spouse or children.

bcl:link.in:doc:
Employment and Assistance for Persons with Disabilities
            Act

bcl:text.#text:
If a victim is not supporting his or her spouse and children and they are likely
          to require income assistance under the  or disability assistance under the , or if an order has been made against the victim by a court of
          competent jurisdiction for the support or maintenance of the spouse or children, the board
          may pay all or part of the compensation to or for the benefit of the spouse or
          children.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
In order to assist a victim to obtain work or to lessen or remove a handicap
        resulting from the injury, the board may take the measures and make expenditures it
        considers necessary or expedient.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
In addition to the other compensation provided by this Act, if the board orders
          periodic payments to be made, the board has authority to furnish or provide for a victim
          medical, surgical, hospital, nursing, and other care or treatment, transportation,
          medicines, crutches, and apparatus, including artificial members, as it considers
          reasonably necessary at the time of the injury.

During the disability, to cure the injury or alleviate its effects, the board may
          adopt rules and regulations for furnishing medical aid to a victim and for payment and the
          board may make a daily subsistence allowance to an injured victim who under its direction,
          is undergoing treatment at a place other than the victim's residence that he or she
          continues to support and maintain.
The board may replace and repair

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
artificial appliances, including artificial members, damaged or broken in
            circumstances set out in section 2 (2), or

clothing, eyeglasses, dentures and hearing aids broken in the same
            circumstances, if the breakage is accompanied by objective signs of personal injury, or,
            if there is no injury, if the crime is otherwise corroborated and the board is satisfied
            that the victim was not at fault.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Medical or hospital costs payable under a medical or hospital plan established
          under any Act of Canada or of British Columbia are not payable under this Act.

bcl:section.bcl:marginalnote: Medical examination and proof of dependency

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The board may require a victim who is receiving periodic payments of compensation
          to be medically examined at a place reasonably convenient for the victim.

If the victim fails to attend for the examination or obstructs the medical
          examiner

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
the victim's right to compensation is suspended until the examination has taken
            place, and
no compensation is payable during the period of suspension.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The board may reduce or suspend periodic payments of compensation if the
          victim

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
persists in unsanitary or injurious practices that tend to imperil or retard his
            or her recovery, or

refuses to submit to medical or surgical treatment that, in the board's opinion,
            based on medical or surgical advice, is reasonably essential to promote his or her
            recovery.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: The board may

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
require proof of the existence and the physical, mental or financial condition
            of an immediate family member receiving compensation, and
withhold further payments until receipt of satisfactory proof.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
If an application for compensation is made to the board, every physician or
          qualified practitioner attending or consulting about the injury or alleged injury to a
          victim must

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
furnish reports about the injury in a form as required by the regulations or by
            the board,

furnish the first report to the board within 3 days after it is requested by the
            board,

furnish a final report within 3 days after the victim is, in the opinion of the
            physician or qualified practitioner, able to resume work and, if treatment is being
            continued after resumption of work, furnish further adequate reports, and

if the physician is a specialist whose opinion is requested by the attending
            physician, the victim, or the board, or if the physician continues to treat the victim
            after being consulted as a specialist, furnish the first report to the board within 3
            days after completion of consultation but, if the specialist is regularly treating the
            victim, the specialist must submit reports as required in paragraphs (a) to (c).

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
Every physician or qualified practitioner who is authorized by this Act to treat
          an injured victim is subject to similar duties and responsibilities, and any aid furnished
          by that person is subject to the direction, supervision and control of the
          board.

bcl:text.#text:
The board is charged with the administration of this Act, and has all the powers
          that are given to it under the .

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
The board has exclusive jurisdiction to inquire into, hear and determine all those
          matters and questions of fact and law arising or required to be determined under this Act,
          and the action or decision of the board is final and conclusive and is not open to
          question or review in any court.

Proceedings by or before the board must not be restrained by injunction,
          prohibition, or other process or proceeding in any court or be removed by certiorari or
          otherwise into any court.

An action must not be maintained or brought against any governor, officer, appeal
          commissioner or employee of the board for any act, omission or decision done or made in
          the genuine belief that it was within the jurisdiction of the board.

Without limiting subsections (1) to (4), the board has exclusive jurisdiction to inquire
          into, hear and determine any of the following:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: whether the victim sustained an injury;
whether an injury to or the death of a victim resulted from

bcl:subparagraph.bcl:text:
his or her making or attempting to make an arrest of an offender or suspected
              offender,

assisting a peace officer in making or attempting to make an
              arrest,

preventing or attempting to prevent the commission of an offence or suspected
              offence, or

assisting a peace officer in preventing or attempting to prevent the
              commission of an offence or suspected offence;

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text: the existence and degree of disability by reason of an injury;
the permanence of disability by reason of an injury;
the degree of diminution of earning capacity by reason of an injury;

the existence, for this Act, of the relationship of any person to the
            victim;
the existence of dependency;
whether any person is entitled to compensation under this Act.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text: [Repealed 2001-38-32 and B.C. Reg. 160/2002.]

The board has the same powers as the Supreme Court for compelling the attendance
          of witnesses and of examining them under oath, and compelling the production and
          inspection of books, papers, documents and things.

The board may cause depositions of witnesses residing in or out of British
          Columbia to be taken before any person appointed by the board in a similar manner to that
          prescribed by the Rules of the Supreme Court for the taking of similar depositions in that
          court before a commissioner.

The board may act on the report of any if its officers, and any inquiry or
          examination that it considers necessary to make may be made by any officer of the board or
          other person appointed to make the inquiry or examination.
[Repealed 2001-38-32 and B.C. Reg. 160/2002.]

A decision of the appeal division or of a panel of the appeal division is deemed
          to be a decision of the board.

An appeal commissioner or officer of the board, a member of an appeal committee,
          and every person appointed to make an inquiry or examination under this section has, for
          the purposes of an inquiry or a review under this section, all the powers conferred upon
          the board by section 20.

An appeal commissioner or officer of the board, a member of an appeal committee
          and every person appointed to make an inquiry or examination under this section has power
          and authority

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
to require and take affidavits, affirmations or declarations relating to the
            examination or inquiry,
to take statutory declarations, and

in all cases to administer oaths, affirmations and declarations and to certify
            them.

bcl:subsection.bcl:text:
A person who obstructs or hinders the making of an examination or inquiry under
          this section, or refuses to permit it to be made, commits an offence.

Subject to this section, a decision of the appeal division is final and
          conclusive.
[Repealed 2001-38-32 and B.C. Reg. 160/2002.]

On or before March 25 in each year, the board must make a report to the Lieutenant
          Governor in Council of its transactions during the last preceding calendar
          year.

The report must contain particulars the Lieutenant Governor in Council may
          specify.

The report must be submitted by the Attorney General to the Legislature or, if it
          is not in session, within 15 days after the opening of the next session.

The board is to publish and distribute information about the business transacted
          by the board as it judges useful.

bcl:section.bcl:text:
The government, represented by the Attorney General, with the approval of the
        Lieutenant Governor in Council, may make agreements with Canada for the payment by Canada to
        the government of part of the expenditures required for this Act.

bcl:text.#text:
This Act applies for compensation claims arising from an injury or death resulting
        from an act or omission that occurs after July 1, 1972 and for which an application is
        received by the board before the date section 2 of the  comes into force.

bcl:section.bcl:text: The Lieutenant Governor in Council may make regulations as follows:

bcl:paragraph.bcl:text:
prescribing rules for applications to the board and the proceedings of the
          board;

requiring the payment of fees for any matter in the jurisdiction of the board,
          including witness fees, and prescribing the amounts;
prescribing forms for this Act and providing for their use;

respecting any matter necessary or advisable to effectively carry out this
          Act;
adding or subtracting offences in the Schedule;

bcl:text.#text:
making any provision of the  applicable, to an extent as may be prescribed, to this
          Act.

oasis:entry.oasis:line: Endangering safety of aircraft in flight.

Taking offensive weapons and explosive substances on board a civilian
                  aircraft.
Explosives where death or bodily harm results.

Intentionally causing death or bodily harm by explosive
                  substance.

Using a firearm while committing or attempting to commit an indictable
                  offence, or during flight after committing or attempting to commit an indictable
                  offence.
Pointing a firearm or careless use of a firearm.

Sexual interference or sexual touching of a person under
                  14.
Sexual exploitation of a young person.
Causing bodily harm by criminal negligence.
Overcoming resistance to commission of offence.
Traps likely to cause bodily harm or death.
Dangerous operation of vessel or towed object.
Operating unseaworthy vessel or unsafe aircraft.
Failure to safeguard opening in ice or excavation on land.
Assault with a weapon or causing bodily harm.

Sexual assault with a weapon, threats to a third party or causing bodily
                  harm.
Abduction in contravention of custody order.
Mischief causing actual danger to life.
Causing fire resulting in loss of life.
